segments.text: This is May 7, a beautiful day in Kerrville, Texas, and sitting in the living room looking out on the golf course with Mr. Porter Garner, Jr. And I should have held this mic up near where I am.
Mr. Garner, say a sentence and let's check yours.
Yes, is it coming through all right?
Let's begin with a brief review of where you were born and grew up and went to high school before you thought about going to A&M.
All right.
I was born in Carnes County, a little community out between Carnes City and Nixon called Mound Creek.
My father was a schoolteacher.
He had a
two teacher school at that time at Mound Creek.
And we moved when I was a babe in arms to Rivera, Texas, down below Kingsville.
It was quite a promotion for my father.
He got about a seven teacher school where he was superintendent there.
After two or three years there,
they built the college in Kingsville, which at that time was called South Texas State Teachers College.
And my father was the first male student to enroll when they built that college.
And because prior to this time, all he had was a teacher's certificate, which he had gained in one semester at, it was not called Southwest,

texas state then it was i believe it was southwest texas normal in san marcos in san marcos he attended there one semester and passed the requirements for a teacher certificate anyway he decided if he was going to stay in the profession he better get him a formal education i know this is kind of running a no no way but anyway he did he finished there in
Kingsville.
He was the night watchman, janitor, did some tutoring on the side and raised a family and finished there in three and a half years and went from there to the little town of Premont as superintendent.
From there to Corn City, Corn City to Robstown,
and Robstown to Victoria and that's where he retired from teaching and we moved to Laredo where he went into private business.
Robstown was dear to me for quite a few reasons but that's where my father first became involved in any way with

Lyndon Johnson and that was strictly because of the Kleberg in Kingsville room Lyndon Johnson worked for Bob Kleberg back at that time as I believe it was called an administrative assistant and it stood well for my father later on because of being able to get things for the schools to the National Youth Administration and
which Johnson was, I would, hold on just a moment.
Anyway, back to the deal.

He got a lot of programs for the different schools where he was located through the National Youth Administration to create jobs for kids that were going to school and had a little problem because we're talking about the,
depression years, and everybody was anxious for all the help they could get.
I'll say that I was quite young at that time, but I do remember a lot of things that at the time didn't necessarily make sense to me, but as I look back I could understand
what took place.
One little thing in, in Robstown, for instance, one of the first schools to ever have a, in South Texas, to have a cafeteria on site.
And all of us in the elementary grades were forced to have lunch at the cafeteria.
And
And the reason for it was to ensure that all children got a hot meal, one hot meal a day, good meal.
And you didn't pay at the cafeteria.
Your homeroom teacher took up the money because she knew who could afford that nickel or dime and who couldn't.
And no one ever knew who paid and who didn't pay.
But anyway, that's neither here nor there.
It's just a little background.
information.
My father, who was my ideal, he was my ideal.
That's the best thing I can say.
Anyway, when I finished high school in Laredo, Texas,
Exactly why I went to Texas A&M, I can't tell you.
Do you know when you first thought about it?
Probably in 1939 and 40.
And it wasn't because of the football team, even though I'm a great football fan.
We had some boys from Laredo who had been friends of mine but were a year ahead of me in school.

and a couple of them that I knew quite well had gone to A&M as freshmen and come home and the things they would talk about and so on just impressed me so that I thought this ought to be a pretty good deal.
Do you remember what it was that they said attracted you?
the camaraderie of the cohesiveness of the students and just so many things like that.
It certainly wasn't the academics because I was like a lot of young kids at that time.
I didn't know what in the world I wanted to do.
My daddy had talked about
how being a doctor would be such a nice thing.
I thought, well, that would be a nice thing to be as a doctor.
I'll just think about that.
Well, these boys, I don't know, if they would have told me everything about being a freshman at A&M, I might not have gone.
But anyway, it was the camaraderie and everything that just,
It was just the thing to do as far as I was concerned.
Did you go visit before you went to enroll?
The first time I ever saw Texas A&M was when my father helped me unload my footlocker out of the back of the car over in what was called at that time the new area.
Now I think they call it the quad or something.
He helped me, set it on the ground there.
We shook hands, and he said, son, you're on your own.
And he drove off.
And it was a rude awakening.
It was different.
Describe those first few hours and days.
Well, when I first looked, I knew, found out that that was dorm...
I mean, dorm four, and that's where I was, no, let's see, dorm six, and that's where I was supposed to be.
I said, well, I can't handle all this I've got here.
So I saw a fella going over towards that door and I said, hey, I said, and fortunately I did introduce myself to him.
And I asked him if he'd help me take that trunk I was supposed to be there.
And so he said, sure.
And so he picked up one end of the trunk, and I had the trunk and a suitcase.
And he helped me carry it in.
And it so happened that I had a corner room assigned to me on the second floor.
And he went right along with me and helped me put that trunk down in that corner room.

I started to unpack and put things around and so on and so forth and all of a sudden a couple of fellas came in and asked me what I was doing and I said well I was just unpacking and he says why here?
And well to make a long story short I was

it was explained to me that I was not going to be in that room, that there had been a mistake in some way, and it would be better for the time being if I just put my things out in the hall and I would be told later where to put them.
Well, that was just, that was my first awakening at being a freshman at Texas A&M University.

So happened that different ones were drifting in and a lot of them in my same shape and it didn't take very long however for us to understand that just take it easy and don't let the mouth get to working too much and see what happens.
Well one thing led to another and we were assigned to different, to roommates and to different rooms and in fact the first night we were there I was initiated in what they called a bleed meeting and
I'm sure you're familiar with it.
Describe yours.
Well, this first one was all the freshmen that were there at the time, and I would say there was, had to be at least 20 of us.
We were in a room, all sitting on the floor.
Sardines had never been packed any tighter than that.
That room is approximately 10 or 12 by 14.
I would, and that's given a little bit.
It certainly wasn't any bigger than that.
And there was a double deck bed in there, a dresser,
two desks, it wasn't a dresser either, there was a medicine cabinet and a sink, and two tables for desks, two chairs.
This doesn't sound like it's possible, but on top of that, there was at least 20 freshmen on the floor, sitting on the beds and on the tables,
for this were sophomores, or pissheads.
And I learned real quick, don't look down, look up.
Even if, whatever, you look right at one of them, don't let your eyes stray away.
And we were given to understand real quick that

I believe the saying went, a freshman was lower than, if you'll just pardon the vernacular because you're going to edit this out, says if a freshman, sir, is the lowest thing imaginable, it's ten times lower than whales shed on the bottom of the ocean.
yet it's 100 times higher than a graduate of Texas University.
And there were a few other little things, but it always ended up with, that, sir, is the definition of a freshman.
Well, it was quickly to be understood that we were there for the, at the pleasure and for the pleasure
of the upperclassmen, and what happened to us was strictly immaterial, supposedly.
It was a full year or more before I learned that these people really and truly cared for us, and that with possibly one or two exceptions, they all turned out to be great

great fellas what was your outfit i was in i battery field artillery did it have a nickname no no it didn't prior the year prior or two years prior it had been called third combat train but they we had to look at our time had the largest freshman class that had ever come to texas a m
we had, if I'm not mistaken, around 1,600 or something in our freshman class.
Now that might miss it a little, but that's pretty close.
you didn't make any choice as to field artillery.
It was selected for you?
No, no.
We had a, we could put down choices.
You didn't necessarily get what you put down, but if your application got in early enough, you probably got what you put down.
And the reason I put field artillery down was the friends of mine from Laredo had said that's probably the best thing.
How do I know?
Now, as you were making that choice, did it ever occur to you that the events that were occurring in Europe might have, wartime events, might have an impact on you?
Let me tell you something about that.
And this is going to be hard for you to believe, but it's the truth.
The majority
of students coming in to Texas A&M at that time were really unconcerned.
Not, didn't, sure we knew that there was problems over there.
We knew that Poland had been invaded.
We knew that
France had been invaded.
But it's very difficult for today's people to, with our instant, instant knowledge and communication of everything all over, to realize back at that time
how something that was taking place in Europe, which was a century away, how it really affected us.
And sure, we knew that it was going on and so on and so forth, but weren't really that concerned.
It was not really truly, truly brought home to us, even though they had started with the peacetime draft.
But it was not truly brought home to us until Pearl Harbor happened.
Describe how you as a freshman got your uniforms and how you and your roommates settled down in your room and so forth.
Well, my roommate was a young man named James Collins from Gonzales, Texas.
Jimmy left after, oh, I don't think he even stayed till midterm.
Let's see.
I guess he did.
He stayed until midterm and went home and never came back after midterm.
And he joined the Air Force and was killed very shortly
first went overseas and was killed almost immediately.
But anyway, we got our issue, all being naturally an ROTC, we got two, let's see, two pair of wool pants, two pair of khaki pants, I believe two khaki shirts,
And as I remember it, that's about the size of the issue.
Now, were shoes part of the issue?
No, no.
You had to buy your shoes.
You had to buy your shoes.
And they were what?
Black?
Oh, no, they were brown.
Brown, okay.
You had to buy a brown shoe, yes, sir.
And?
Hat, you bought your hat.
I came to school with my hat.
I bought my hat in Laredo.
And let's see.
In fact, I think that that was about the only issue that we had, even though we only wore khakis and uniform.
I mean, there was no such thing, especially for a freshman,
to not wear anything but the uniform.
Did the clothes fit your uniform?
Pretty closely.
I was of about a normal size, I would say, at that time, and I didn't have a lot of problems that way.
Clothes fit pretty well.
But, you know, as well as they're going to fit.
But anyway, we didn't have too much problem there.
And things went along pretty normal.
It was one thing to learn about being set on details and all of this stuff.
And the fact was that your life just wasn't your own, that's all.
But they were very, very protective when it came to

school from seven o'clock in the evening until eleven o'clock or no no eleven o'clock that's right eleven o'clock until the grades came out you had to be sitting at your desk whether you were studying or what you had to be sitting there and if you're going to be sitting there you might as well be studying or reading something after the grades came out
big concession.
If you were passing, had 17 hours and 17 grade points, you could go to bed at 10 o'clock.
So that was a big concession.
That was your, in the Aggie lingo, then your fish old lady left fairly soon.
Right.
Were you then without a roommate?
No, no, no, no, no.
There was quite a few left.
But a lot of them left when the grades came out.
And there was no problem in filling up the space there.
So I got...
In fact, during my time at A&M, I had, before I went into the service, which we were there a long time after we went in the service, before I went in the service, I had three different roommates.
And the one left at midterm, the next one left at the end of the long term,
And then we had a, we went over to three semesters a year, starting in September of 42, I guess it was.
Not September, May, around May of 42.
And that boy left then and went into the Navy.
Then we went in.
We were inducted, let's say.
No, we weren't inducted until early 43.
Officially, we were inducted December of 1942.
We had joined what was called the Enlisted Reserve Corps.
They came to A&M with different propositions.
The Navy had a V-12 program.
And, of course, we always asked, how long can we stay in school?
Can't promise you a thing, boys, but we'd like to have you in our program.
The Marines came with a program called, I don't know, V-something else.
and how long can we stay in school?
I said, I can't promise you a thing.
The Army came with the Enlisted Reserve Corps.
How long can we stay in school?
As long as you keep your grades up.
Where do we sign?
As far as I know, the Navy boys and the Marines might still be down there at College Station, but they pulled us out.
they didn't adhere to their promise that they made, which I can understand those things.
And we were pulled out and sent to different places to be inducted.
I happened to be sent to Louisiana to... Polk?
Livingston?
Livingston, Camp Livingston.
Actually, it was Camp Beauregard, which was just a few miles from Livingston, and they inducted us there.
They took us over to Livingston to do everything, but we were actually sleeping at Camp Beauregard.
Let's go back to this freshman year, first of all.
Did you have a major?
Yes.
a major in zoology and with a minor in chemistry.
I was taking a pre-medical.
Do you remember what courses you had that first fall?
I guess.
I had English, Algebra, Biology, Chemistry, English,
English, algebra, math.
Math, history.
The what?
Math or history.
I had algebra.
Oh, algebra.
Okay.
You mentioned it.
And let's see.
I had one other.
Oh, and German.
German.
I was thinking German.
And physical education.
Do you remember some of those teachers?
Yes.
Describe them, please.
All right.
I had a...
biology teacher that I can't call his name, but he was a wonderful, wonderful teacher.
I had an algebra teacher that was horrible.
I say that without any rancor towards him.
The story was that he had always taught advanced calculus, but with the terrific influx of students, he was pressed into service to teach freshman algebra.
I question not his abilities as a mathematician.
He was brilliant.
But to teach a bunch of us freshman algebra, it was something else.
I hadn't had enough in high school to begin with.
And his name was Halperin, Dutch Halperin.
Somebody made the mistake of saying Dr. Halperin.
He was not Dr. Halperin.
He would let you know that.
He had a lot of little idiosyncrasies.
He could draw a line across that board like that that you couldn't draw with a straightedge.
But up and down, it was like...
He, you know, tells us very often, he says, you are dumb.
You are so dumb.
He says, you should be in kindergarten.
Now, the Dutch came from his Germanic right.
And he would, he'd say, you know, he says, you ought to be like me.
Well, I'm getting ahead of myself, but there was a boy in our class
named Dean.
His last name was Dean.
He was from Austin, Texas.
Pretty smart boy, but he was having a hard time as a freshman.
He was in the cavalry, and he was in, I believe, C Troop, and they were notorious for the way the freshmen were treated.
And Dean was having trouble staying awake in class, and he had been to sleep several times in Halpert's class,
Finally Halperin one day just started reading a riot act to him and told him about, says, says, Dean said, you are so dumb.
And he says, you should be like me.
He says, I speak six different languages.
Dean said, and if you could speak English, you'd make seven.
Well, Halperin would just fall about that big.
Dean got up.
He was smart.
He got up, got his books, and walked right out of the class.
But he went right straight to Dean Brooks' office.
Dean Brooks was a fine man.
Got in to see Dean Brooks, told him the whole story of what happened, and told him, and he convinced him.
He said, Dean Brooks says, I'm not as dumb as this fellow thinks.
and says, if you will take a chance on me and assign me to another section, he says, I'll show you what I can do.
And Dean Brooks did, and Dean did, and Dean turned out to be a very good student.
That's just one little thing that happened.
Let's see, what about the other classes?
I had a... Chemistry?
Chemistry was a lecture.
And then the one that was in charge of our section, well, we had a lab.
